head.title: Fast methods for computing the Neuberger Operator

h1.span: Fast methods for computing the Neuberger Operator

span.span:
Artan BoriÃ§i
Paul Scherrer Institute
CH-5232 Villigen PSI
Artan.Borici@psi.ch
Talk given at the â€œInterdisciplinary Workshop on Numerical Challenges to Lattice QCDâ€, Wuppertal, 22-24 August 1999

div.p: I describe a Lanczos method to compute the Neuberger Operator and a multigrid algorithm for its inversion.

Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) is a theory of strong interactions, where the chiral symmetry plays a mayor role. There are different starting points to formulate a lattice theory with exact chiral symmetry, but all of them must obey the Ginsparg-Wilson condition [1]:

semantics.annotation: italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-D POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-D POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-a italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-alpha POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where ağ‘italic-aa is the lattice spacing, Dğ·italic-DD is the lattice Dirac operator and Î±-1superscriptğ›¼1italic-alpha POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\alpha}^{-1} is a local operator and trivial in the Dirac space.
A candidate is the overlap operator of Neuberger [2]:

semantics.annotation: italic-D RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-A OPEN:( italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-A RELOP:equals italic-M ADDOP:minus italic-a italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

div.p: where Mğ‘€italic-MM is a shift parameter in the range (0,2)02OPEN:( NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 CLOSE:)(0,2), which I have fixed at one and DWsubscriptğ·ğ‘Šitalic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:endD_{W} is the Wilson-Dirac operator,

semantics.annotation: italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:[ italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OPERATOR:partial-differential POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus OPERATOR:partial-differential POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-a OPERATOR:partial-differential POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPERATOR:partial-differential POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:]
D_{W}=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{\mu}[\gamma_{\mu}(\partial_{\mu}^{*}+\partial_{\mu})-a% \partial_{\mu}^{*}\partial_{\mu}]

div.p: and âˆ‚Î¼subscriptğœ‡OPERATOR:partial-differential POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\partial_{\mu} and âˆ‚Î¼*superscriptsubscriptğœ‡OPERATOR:partial-differential POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\partial_{\mu}^{*} are the nearest-neighbor forward and backward difference operators, which are covariant, i.e. the shift operators pick up a unitary 3 by 3 matrix with determinant one. These small matrices are associated with the links of the lattice and are oriented positively. A set of such matrices forms a â€configurationâ€. Î³Î¼,Î¼=1,â€¦,5formulae-sequencesubscriptğ›¾ğœ‡ğœ‡1â€¦5italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-mu RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, ID:ldots PUNCT:, NUMBER:5\gamma_{\mu},\mu=1,\ldots,5 are 4 by 4 matrices related to the spin of the particle. Therefore, if there are Nğ‘italic-NN lattice points, the matrix is of order 12â¢N12ğ‘NUMBER:12 italic-N12N. A restive symmetry of the matrix Ağ´italic-AA that comes from the continuum is the so called Î³5-sâ¢yâ¢mâ¢mâ¢eâ¢tâ¢râ¢ysubscriptğ›¾5ğ‘ ğ‘¦ğ‘šğ‘šğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¦italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-s italic-y italic-m italic-m italic-e italic-t italic-r italic-y\gamma_{5}-symmetry which is the Hermiticity of the Î³5â¢Asubscriptğ›¾5ğ´italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-A\gamma_{5}A operator.

br.p: The computation of the inverse square root of a matrix is reviewed in [3]. In the context of lattice QCD there are several sparse matrix methods, which are developed recently [4, 5, 6, 7, 8]. I will focus here on a Lanczos method similar to [4]. For a more general case of functions of matrices I refer to the talk of H. van der Vorst, and for a Chebyshev method I refer to the talk of K. Jansen, both included in these proceedings.

div.p: The Lanczos iteration is known to approximate the spectrum of the underlying matrix in an optimal way and, in particular, it can be used to solve linear systems [9].

Let Qn=[q1,â€¦,qn]subscriptğ‘„ğ‘›subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:[ italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:ldots PUNCT:, italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:]Q_{n}=[q_{1},\ldots,q_{n}] be the set of orthonormal vectors, such that

semantics.annotation: italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-b PUNCT:, italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| italic-b VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

div.p: where Tnsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{n} is a tridiagonal and symmetric matrix, bğ‘italic-bb is an arbitrary vector, and Î²nsubscriptğ›½ğ‘›italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\beta_{n} a real and positive constant. em(n)superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘šğ‘›italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ende_{m}^{(n)} denotes the unit vector with nğ‘›italic-nn elements in the direction mğ‘šitalic-mm.

By writing down the above decomposition in terms of the vectors qi,i=1,â€¦,nformulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘›italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-i RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, ID:ldots PUNCT:, italic-nq_{i},i=1,\ldots,n and the matrix elements of Tnsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{n}, I arrive at a three term recurrence that allows to compute these vectors in increasing order, starting from the vector q1subscriptğ‘1italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endq_{1}. This is the Lâ¢aâ¢nâ¢câ¢zâ¢oâ¢sâ¢Aâ¢lâ¢gâ¢oâ¢râ¢iâ¢tâ¢hâ¢mğ¿ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘§ğ‘œğ‘ ğ´ğ‘™ğ‘”ğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¡â„ğ‘šitalic-L italic-a italic-n italic-c italic-z italic-o italic-s italic-A italic-l italic-g italic-o italic-r italic-i italic-t italic-h italic-mLanczosAlgorithm:

semantics.annotation: ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| italic-b VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-o PUNCT:, italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-b CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start italic-f italic-o italic-r italic-i RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, ID:ldots CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start italic-v RELOP:equals italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-v CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start italic-v RELOP:assign italic-v ADDOP:minus italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| italic-v VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start italic-i italic-f italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-t italic-o italic-l PUNCT:, italic-n RELOP:equals italic-i PUNCT:, italic-e italic-n italic-d italic-f italic-o italic-r CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-v MULOP:divide italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end

div.p: where tâ¢oâ¢lğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘™italic-t italic-o italic-ltol is a tolerance which serves as a stopping condition.
The Lanczos Algorithm constructs a basis for the Krylov subspace [9]:

semantics.annotation: ATOM:span OPEN:{ italic-b PUNCT:, italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A italic-b PUNCT:, ID:ldots PUNCT:, OPEN:( italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-b CLOSE:}
\mbox{span}\{b,A^{{\dagger}}Ab,\ldots,(A^{{\dagger}}A)^{n-1}b\}

div.p: If the Algorithm stops after nğ‘›italic-nn steps, one says that the associated Krylov subspace is invariant.

In the floating point arithmetic, there is a danger that once the Lanczos Algorithm (polynomial) has approximated well some part of the spectrum, the iteration reproduces vectors which are rich in that direction [9]. As a consequence, the orthogonality of the Lanczos vectors is spoiled with an immediate impact on the history of the iteration: if the algorithm would stop after nğ‘›italic-nn steps in exact arithmetic, in the presence of round off errors the loss of orthogonality would keep the algorithm going on.

section.h2: 3 The Lanczos Algorithm for solving Aâ€ â¢Aâ¢x=bsuperscriptğ´â€ ğ´ğ‘¥ğ‘italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A italic-x RELOP:equals italic-bA^{{\dagger}}Ax=b

div.p: Here I will use this algorithm to solve linear systems, where the loss of orthogonality will not play a role in the sense that I will use a different stopping condition.
I ask the solution in the form

semantics.annotation: italic-x RELOP:equals italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
x=Q_{n}y_{n}

div.p: By projecting the original system on to the Krylov subspace I get:

semantics.annotation: italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A italic-x RELOP:equals italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-b
Q_{n}^{{\dagger}}A^{{\dagger}}Ax=Q_{n}^{{\dagger}}b

div.p: By construction, I have

semantics.annotation: italic-b RELOP:equals italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: Substituting x=Qnâ¢ynğ‘¥subscriptğ‘„ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›italic-x RELOP:equals italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:endx=Q_{n}y_{n} and using (4), my task is now to solve the system

semantics.annotation: italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

div.p: Therefore the solution is given by

semantics.annotation: italic-x RELOP:equals italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

div.p: This way using the Lanczos iteration one reduces the size of the matrix to be inverted. Moreover, since Tnsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{n} is tridiagonal, one can compute ynsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:endy_{n} by short recurences.
If I define:

semantics.annotation: italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-b ADDOP:minus italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

div.p: where i=1,â€¦ğ‘–1â€¦italic-i RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, ID:ldotsi=1,\ldots, it is easy to show that

semantics.annotation: ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end

section.h2: 4 The Lanczos Algorithm for solving (Aâ€ â¢A)1/2â¢x=bsuperscriptsuperscriptğ´â€ ğ´12ğ‘¥ğ‘OPEN:( italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-x RELOP:equals italic-b(A^{{\dagger}}A)^{1/2}x=b

div.p: Now I would like to compute x=(Aâ€ â¢A)-1/2â¢bğ‘¥superscriptsuperscriptğ´â€ ğ´12ğ‘italic-x RELOP:equals OPEN:( italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-bx=(A^{{\dagger}}A)^{-1/2}b and still use the Lanczos Algorithm. In order to do so I make the following observations:

Let (Aâ€ â¢A)-1/2superscriptsuperscriptğ´â€ ğ´12OPEN:( italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end(A^{{\dagger}}A)^{-1/2} be expressed by a matrix-valued function, for example the integral formula [3]:

semantics.annotation: OPEN:( italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end ARG:start italic-pi ARG:end INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-t OPEN:( italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: From the previous section, I use the Lanczos Algorithm to compute

semantics.annotation: OPEN:( italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-b RELOP:equals italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

div.p: It is easy to show that the Lanczos Algorithm is shift-invariant. i.e. if the matrix Aâ€ â¢Asuperscriptğ´â€ ğ´italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-AA^{{\dagger}}A is shifted by a constant say, t2superscriptğ‘¡2italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endt^{2}, the Lanczos vectors remain invariant. Moreover, the corresponding Lanczos matrix is shifted by the same amount.

This property allows one to solve the system (t2+Aâ€ â¢A)â¢x=bsuperscriptğ‘¡2superscriptğ´â€ ğ´ğ‘¥ğ‘OPEN:( italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A CLOSE:) italic-x RELOP:equals italic-b(t^{2}+A^{{\dagger}}A)x=b by using the same Lanczos iteration as before. Since the matrix (t2+Aâ€ â¢A)superscriptğ‘¡2superscriptğ´â€ ğ´OPEN:( italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A CLOSE:)(t^{2}+A^{{\dagger}}A) is better conditioned than Aâ€ â¢Asuperscriptğ´â€ ğ´italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-AA^{{\dagger}}A, it can be concluded that once the original system is solved, the shifted one is solved too. Therefore I have:

semantics.annotation: OPEN:( italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-b RELOP:equals italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

div.p: Using the above integral formula and puting everything together, I get:

semantics.annotation: italic-x RELOP:equals OPEN:( italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-b RELOP:equals italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

div.p: There are some remarks to be made here:

a) As before, by applying the Lanczos iteration on Aâ€ â¢Asuperscriptğ´â€ ğ´italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-AA^{{\dagger}}A, the problem of computing (Aâ€ â¢A)-1/2â¢bsuperscriptsuperscriptğ´â€ ğ´12ğ‘OPEN:( italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-b(A^{{\dagger}}A)^{-1/2}b reduces to the problem of computing yn=Tn-1/2â¢e1(n)/Ï1subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›12superscriptsubscriptğ‘’1ğ‘›subscriptğœŒ1italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endy_{n}=T_{n}^{-1/2}e_{1}^{(n)}/\rho_{1} which is typically a much smaller problem than the original one. But since Tn1/2superscriptsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›12italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT_{n}^{1/2} is full, ynsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:endy_{n} cannot be computed by short recurences. It can be computed for example by using the full decomposition of Tnsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{n} in its eigenvalues and eigenvectors; in fact this is the method I have employed too, for its compactness and the small overhead for moderate nğ‘›italic-nn.

b) The method is not optimal, as it would have been, if one would have applied it directly for the matrix (Aâ€ â¢A)1/2superscriptsuperscriptğ´â€ ğ´12OPEN:( italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end(A^{{\dagger}}A)^{1/2}. By using Aâ€ â¢Asuperscriptğ´â€ ğ´italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-AA^{{\dagger}}A the condition is squared, and one looses a factor of two compared to the theoretical case!

c) From the derivation above, it can be concluded that the system (Aâ€ â¢A)1/2â¢x=bsuperscriptsuperscriptğ´â€ ğ´12ğ‘¥ğ‘OPEN:( italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-x RELOP:equals italic-b(A^{{\dagger}}A)^{1/2}x=b is solved at the same time as the system Aâ€ â¢Aâ¢x=bsuperscriptğ´â€ ğ´ğ‘¥ğ‘italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A italic-x RELOP:equals italic-bA^{{\dagger}}Ax=b.
d) To implement the result (18), I first construct the Lanczos matrix and then compute

semantics.annotation: italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

div.p: To compute x=Qnâ¢ynğ‘¥subscriptğ‘„ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›italic-x RELOP:equals italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:endx=Q_{n}y_{n}, I repeat the Lanczos iteration. I save the scalar products, though it is not necessary.

Therefore I have the following Algorithm2 for solving the system (Aâ€ â¢A)1/2â¢x=bsuperscriptsuperscriptğ´normal-â€ ğ´12ğ‘¥ğ‘OPEN:( italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-x RELOP:equals italic-b(A^{{\dagger}}A)^{1/2}x=b:

POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| italic-b VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-o PUNCT:, italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-b CELL:end ROW:end italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-i CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start italic-v RELOP:equals italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start italic-v RELOP:assign italic-v ADDOP:minus italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-v MULOP:divide italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end

div.p: where by oğ‘œitalic-oo I denote a vector with zero entries and Un,Î›nsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘›subscriptÎ›ğ‘›italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{n},\Lambda_{n} the matrices of the egienvectors and eigenvalues of Tnsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{n}. Note that there are only four large vectors necessary to store: qi-1,qi,v,xisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘£subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-v PUNCT:, italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endq_{i-1},q_{i},v,x_{i}.

I propose a simple test: I solve the system Aâ€ â¢Aâ¢x=bsuperscriptğ´â€ ğ´ğ‘¥ğ‘italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A italic-x RELOP:equals italic-bA^{{\dagger}}Ax=b by applying twice the Aâ¢lâ¢gâ¢oâ¢râ¢iâ¢tâ¢hâ¢mâ¢2ğ´ğ‘™ğ‘”ğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¡â„ğ‘š2italic-A italic-l italic-g italic-o italic-r italic-i italic-t italic-h italic-m NUMBER:2Algorithm2, i.e. I solve the linear systems

semantics.annotation: OPEN:( italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-z RELOP:equals italic-b PUNCT:, OPEN:( italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-x RELOP:equals italic-z

div.p: in the above order. For each approximation xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endx_{i}, I compute the residual vector

semantics.annotation: italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-b ADDOP:minus italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
r_{i}=b-A^{{\dagger}}Ax_{i}

div.p: The method is tested for a SU(3) configuration at Î²=6.0ğ›½6.0italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:6.0\beta=6.0 on a 83â¢16superscript8316NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end NUMBER:168^{3}16 lattice, corresponding to an order 9830498304NUMBER:9830498304 complex matrix Ağ´italic-AA.

In Fig.1 I show the norm of the residual vector decreasing monotonically. The stagnation of ||ri||2subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–2VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end||r_{i}||_{2} for small values of tâ¢oâ¢lğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘™italic-t italic-o italic-ltol may come from the accumulation of round off error in the 6464NUMBER:6464-bit precision arithmetic used here.

This example shows that the tolerance line is above the residual norm line, which confirms the expectation that tâ¢oâ¢lğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘™italic-t italic-o italic-ltol is a good stopping condition of the Aâ¢lâ¢gâ¢oâ¢râ¢iâ¢tâ¢hâ¢mâ¢2ğ´ğ‘™ğ‘”ğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¡â„ğ‘š2italic-A italic-l italic-g italic-o italic-r italic-i italic-t italic-h italic-m NUMBER:2Algorithm2.

Having computed the operator, one can invert it by applying iterative methods based on the the Lanczos algorithm. Since the operator Dğ·italic-DD is normal, it turns out that the Conjugate Residual (CR) algorithm is the optimal one [10].
Therefore, other ideas are needed.

The essential point is the large number of small eigenvalues of Ağ´italic-AA that make the computation of Dğ·italic-DD time consuming. Therefore, one may try to project out these modes and invert them directly [11].
Also, one may try 5-limit-from5NUMBER:5 ADDOP:minus5-dimensional implementations of the Neuberger operator, such that its condition improves [12].
I have tried also to reformulate the theory in 5 dimensions by using the corresponding approximate inversion as a coarse grid solution in a multigrid scheme [13].
The scheme is tested and the results are shown in Fig. 2, where the multigrid pattern of the residual norm is clear. The gain with respect to CR is about a factor 1010NUMBER:1010.

Note that to invert the â€œbigâ€ matrix I have used the BiCGstab2 algorithm [14] which is almost optimal in most of the cases for the non-normal matrices as its is the matrix â„³â„³caligraphic-M\cal M [10].
The author would like to thank the organizers of this Workshop for the kind hospitality at Wuppertal.

H. Neuberger, Phys. Lett. B 417 (1998) 141, Phys. Rev. D 57 (1998) 5417.
N. J. Higham, Proceedings of â€Pure and Applied Linear Algebra: The New Generationâ€, Pensacola, March 1993.
R. G. Edwards, U. M. Heller and R. Narayanan, Nucl.Phys. B540 (1999) 457-471.
P. Hernandes, K. Jansen, L. Lellouch, these proceedings and hep-lat/0001008.
G. H. Golub and C. F. Van Loan, Matrix Computations, The Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 1989. This is meant as a general reference with original references included therein.
A. BoriÃ§i, Krylov Subspace Methods in Lattice QCD, PhD Thesis, CSCS TR-96-27, ETH ZÃ¼rich 1996.
R. G. Edwards, U. M. Heller, J. Kiskis, R. Narayanan, hep-lat/9912042.
M. H. Gutknecht, SIAM J. Sci. Comput., 14 (1993) 1020.

figure.figcaption: Figure 1: The dots show the norm of the residual vector, whereas the line shows the tolerance level set by tâ¢oâ¢lğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘™italic-t italic-o italic-ltol in the Aâ¢lâ¢gâ¢oâ¢râ¢iâ¢tâ¢hâ¢mâ¢2ğ´ğ‘™ğ‘”ğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¡â„ğ‘š2italic-A italic-l italic-g italic-o italic-r italic-i italic-t italic-h italic-m NUMBER:2Algorithm2.

Figure 2: Norm of the residual error vs. the number of DWsubscriptğ·ğ‘Šitalic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:endD_{W} multiplications on 30 configurations. Circles stand for the straightforward inversion with CR and stars for the multigrid algorithm.
